title: How to integrate $ \int\frac {5} {\ 16 + 9cos^2(x)} \,dx $ (calculus, integration, math) - Quora

response.answer_text: [math]\displaystyle\int\dfrac{5}{16 + 9\cos^2 x}\,dx[/math] [math]=\dfrac{5}{16 (\cos^2 x + \sin^2 x) + 9 \cos^2 x}\,dx[/math] [math]=\displaystyle\int\dfrac{5}{25\cos^2 x + 16 \sin^2 x}\,dx[/math] [math]=\displaystyle\int \dfrac{5\sec^2 x}{25 + 16 \tan^2 x}[/math] [math]=\dfrac{5}{4}\displaystyle\int\dfrac{4\sec^2 x}{5^2 + (4\tan x)^2}\,dx[/math] [math]=\dfrac{5}{4}\left(\dfrac{1}{5}\right)\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{4\tan x}{5}\right) + C[/math] [math]=\dfrac{1}{4}\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{4\tan x}{5}\right) + C[/math]

[math]\begin{array}{l}\quad \int \dfrac{5}{16+9 \cos ^{2} x} d x \\ =5 \int \dfrac{\sec ^{2} x}{16 \sec ^{2} x+9} d x \\ =5 \int \dfrac{d(\tan x)}{16\left(1+\tan ^{2} x\right)+9} \\ =\dfrac{5}{4} \int \dfrac{d(4 \tan x)}{5^{2}+(4 \tan x)^{2}} \\ =\dfrac{1}{4} \tan ^{-1}\left(\dfrac{4 \tan x}{5}\right)+c\end{array}[/math]
